title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the major grassland present within 20 degrees north and south of the equator as Savanna.
The response identifies the major grassland present within 20 degrees north and south of the equator as Savanna.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the rate of cycling of carbon is slower in a tundra than in a savanna, such as any of the following:

· Carbon cycling in the tundra will occur at a lower rate than in the savanna because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity in a tundra because there are colder temperatures.

· Carbon cycling in the tundra will occur at a lower rate than in the savanna because there are lower rates of decomposition in a tundra from colder temperatures.

· The tundra is a carbon sink, so more carbon is held in the soil than is released into the atmosphere; therefore, the rate of cycling is lower.

· Carbon cycling in the savanna will occur at a higher rate than in the tundra because there are warmer temperatures.

The response explains why the rate of cycling of carbon is slower in a tundra than in a savanna, such as one of the following:

· Carbon cycling in the tundra will occur at a lower rate than in the savanna because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity in a tundra because there are colder temperatures.

· Carbon cycling in the tundra will occur at a lower rate than in the savanna because there are lower rates of decomposition in a tundra from colder temperatures.

· The tundra is a carbon sink, so more carbon is held in the soil than is released into the atmosphere; therefore, the rate of cycling is lower.

· Carbon cycling in the savanna will occur at a higher rate than in the tundra because there are warmer temperatures.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the statement that a tropical wet forest would likely have a higher biodiversity than a tropical dry forest such as the following:

· With more water available, there is more primary production. More plant biomass at the base of the food web can support more organisms, making it likely that there is more diversity.

The response makes a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the statement that a tropical wet forest would likely have a higher biodiversity than a tropical dry forest such as the following:

· With more water available, there is more primary production. More plant biomass at the base of the food web can support more organisms, making it likely that there is more diversity.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a species of bird on a remote island could lose the ability to fly over time, such as any of the following:

· If there are no predators present, there is no selective pressure to fly away and individuals born without the ability to fly survive to reproduce if there is adequate food, passing the flightless genes to offspring, leaving a population of flightless birds.

· The energetic cost of flight was not advantageous on the island, so over time, the genes/alleles for the ability were not selected for and eventually eliminated from the species.

· Genetic mutation and natural selection occur over many generations, leading to a population of flightless birds over time.

The response explains how a species of bird on a remote island could lose the ability to fly over time, such as one of the following:

· If there are no predators present, there is no selective pressure to fly away and individuals born without the ability to fly survive to reproduce if there is adequate food, passing the flightless genes to offspring, leaving a population of flightless birds.

· The energetic cost of flight was not advantageous on the island, so over time, the genes/alleles for the ability were not selected for and eventually eliminated from the species.

· Genetic mutation and natural selection occur over many generations, leading to a population of flightless birds over time.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or opposes the proposal to build a new geothermal power plant in a city located on the interior of the North American Plate to provide electricity for a new housing development such as the following:

· Geothermal energy is available at levels suitable for a power plant near plate boundaries or in areas that are geologically active. The interior of the North American plate or any tectonic plate is unlikely to be a good site for a geothermal power, so this proposal should be opposed.

The response makes a claim using evidence that supports or opposes the proposal to build a new geothermal power plant in a city located on the interior of the North American Plate to provide electricity for a new housing development such as the following:

· Geothermal energy is available at levels suitable for a power plant near plate boundaries or in areas that are geologically active. The interior of the North American plate or any tectonic plate is unlikely to be a good site for a geothermal power, so this proposal should be opposed.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how the shift from agricultural crops to native plants may impact the biodiversity of insect populations, such as any of the following:

· Native plants offer a greater variety of niches/microhabitats for insect populations than agricultural crops do, which will result in an increase in the biodiversity of insect populations.

· Agricultural crops are usually monocultures that reduce plant diversity, thereby reducing insect diversity.

· Presence of more than one species of native plant will increase the diversity of insects.

The response describes how the shift from agricultural crops to native plants may impact the biodiversity of insect populations, such as one of the following:

· Native plants offer a greater variety of niches/microhabitats for insect populations than agricultural crops do, which will result in an increase in the biodiversity of insect populations.

· Agricultural crops are usually monocultures that reduce plant diversity, thereby reducing insect diversity.

· Presence of more than one species of native plant will increase the diversity of insects.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify a variable that should be constant between the two study sites, such as any of the following:

· Quantity of leaf litter collected

· The time of day at which the leaf litter was collected

· Methods used to collect samples (e.g. type of device, depth of sample collection, storage/preservation/treatment of samples)

· Dimensions of area sampled

· Quantity of leaf litter collected

· The time of day at which the leaf litter was collected

· Methods used to collect samples (e.g. type of device, depth of sample collection, storage/preservation/treatment of samples)

· Dimensions of area sampled

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the effect that canopy cover would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as any of the following:

· With less canopy cover, there would be fewer trees/fewer leaves, which would decrease the amount of leaf litter and lower biodiversity at the sites.

· With more canopy cover, there would be more trees/more leaves, which would increase the amount of leaf litter and increase biodiversity at the sites.

· Degree of canopy will affect sunlight, temperature, precipitation which can affect the conditions in the soil and in the litter, which could increase or decrease biodiversity.

· Less canopy cover would increase possibility of greater erosion, which would likely decrease biodiversity.

The response describes the effect that canopy cover would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as one of the following:

· With less canopy cover, there would be fewer trees/fewer leaves, which would decrease the amount of leaf litter and lower biodiversity at the sites.

· With more canopy cover, there would be more trees/more leaves, which would increase the amount of leaf litter and increase biodiversity at the sites.

· Degree of canopy will affect sunlight, temperature, precipitation which can affect the conditions in the soil and in the litter, which could increase or decrease biodiversity.

· Less canopy cover would increase possibility of greater erosion, which would likely decrease biodiversity.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how modifying the experiment to collect samples from wet and dry sites could alter the results of the experiment, such as any of the following:

· Increased soil moisture would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter leading to higher biodiversity at the sites.

· Wet sites would be more likely to have increased leaf litter and higher biodiversity over dry sites.

· Decreased soil moisture would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and lower biodiversity at the sites.

· Dry sites would likely have less leaf litter and lower biodiversity than wet sites.

· Insect species have different tolerance levels for moisture, so moisture level could affect insect diversity.

The response explains how modifying the experiment to collect samples from wet and dry sites could alter the results of the experiment, such as one of the following:

· Increased soil moisture would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter leading to higher biodiversity at the sites.

· Wet sites would be more likely to have increased leaf litter and higher biodiversity over dry sites.

· Decreased soil moisture would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and lower biodiversity at the sites.

· Dry sites would likely have less leaf litter and lower biodiversity than wet sites.

· Insect species have different tolerance levels for moisture, so moisture level could affect insect diversity.
